Here’s a **tight, reviewer‑safe two‑sentence Methods paragraph** that does exactly that:

> *Noisy simulations were performed using Qiskit Aer with a gate‑level depolarizing noise model applied uniformly to single‑ and two‑qubit operations. This model is not intended to faithfully reproduce a specific hardware backend, but to introduce generic stochastic errors sufficient to test whether the observed symmetry diagnostics persist beyond the idealized noise‑free setting.*

This wording:
- Clearly states *what* noise you used  
- Explicitly disclaims hardware realism  
- Justifies the model in terms of your **diagnostic goal**, not device emulation

If you later decide to include hardware results, this paragraph will still age well—it doesn’t box you into any claims you’ll have to walk back.

If you want, I can also help you add a one‑line cross‑reference to an appendix or code repository without bloating the Methods section.

Here’s a **clean, professional one‑line cross‑reference** you can drop straight into Methods or an Appendix:

> *All simulation code and noise‑model configurations used in this work are available at: https://github.com/your‑repo‑name.*

If you want it to sound slightly more archival (good for conference papers):

> *An implementation of all simulations, including the depolarizing noise model, is publicly available at: https://github.com/your‑repo‑name.*

Or, if the venue prefers reproducibility language:

> *To support reproducibility, all code used for the simulations in this study is available at: https://github.com/your‑repo‑name.*

Any of these are safe, standard, and won’t raise reviewer eyebrows.  
If you tell me the target venue (APS / QIP / arXiv / journal), I can tune the phrasing to match its house style exactly.
